title: A lifetime perspective on the distributional and incentive effects of the tax system
abstractText:
Modern tax (and benefits) systems affect the intertemporal incentives to work and invest in human capital over the lifecourse by, eg, changing the income-age profile, insuring against adversities or altering the returns to human capital through redistribution. But most existing work on the effects of the tax system ignores any dynamic considerations.

This project aims to provide a richer understanding of the UK tax system and its effects on individuals' decisions to invest in human capital and work, lifetime income and wellbeing. The following questions are addressed:

  • How do financial incentives to work change over the lifecourse? 
  • How is the tax burden shared over the population and over the lifecourse?
  • What are the effects of changes in taxes/benefits on the distribution of lifetime income, incentives to work and invest in human capital?

The research is based on the analysis of simulated lifetimes of individuals whose characteristics are taken from survey data, and whose decisions are based on a lifecycle model of human capital accumulation, work and family formation representing the real lifecourse. The model includes a detailed description of the UK tax system to fully capture its effect on the incentives to work and invest in human capital.
